name: (2E)-2-(1,3-benzothiazol-2-yl)-3-(4-methylphenyl)prop-2-enamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1263

name: (2E)-2-(1,3-benzothiazol-2-yl)-3-(4-methylphenyl)prop-2-enamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1263
Reason: The compound in question, (2E)-2-(1,3-benzothiazol-2-yl)-3-(4-methylphenyl)prop-2-enamide, has several structural components that can influence its melting point. Starting with benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius, we find that each additional structural feature contributes to the melting point in different ways. The presence of the 1,3-benzothiazole brings in a heterocyclic component and nitrogen and sulfur atoms which can lead to an increase in melting point due to additional pi-pi stacking and potential hydrogen bonding, which we can estimate as +60 degrees Celsius. The amide functional group contributes to melting point elevation through strong hydrogen-bonding capabilities; we can approximate this as +80 degrees Celsius. A single methyl group attached to the phenyl ring likely provides a smaller change, possibly increasing the melting point by around +5 degrees Celsius, considering its inductive effect and minor steric hindrance. Adding these adjustments to the base melting point of benzene, we arrive at a predicted melting point for the compound.
